subject: RE: [junit] Why bother?
messageBody:
Good observations Mathieu! Thanks.

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Mathieu Gervais [mailto:egoine_@...]
> Sent: Monday, June 11, 2001 9:22 AM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [junit] Why bother?
>
>
> >To further David's point... my experience is that most
> main()'s test for
> best-case scenarios. They don't fully test the class.
>
> But they could. Junit does not ensure all scenarios are
> covered, and tests
> written in main methods can be better than tests written
> with Junit.
> The original poster wanted to know how to convince people
> to use junit, but
> those people seem to :
> 1)already write unit tests
> 2) "get it"
>
> So, my opinion is that your use the junit framework to:
>
> A-have a standard way of writing and *running* tests. If
> each developer has
> it's own little main class, how does one know how to
> invoke it, where it is,
> how to check for ouput. Of course, they can all be
> written the same way,
> stored at the same place, and all return a exit code to indicate
> success/failure let's say. But why bother to establish
> such standards when
> using junit gives you all that by default (there is test
> collectors written
> for junit). With junit, I feel it's easier for someone
> to say : "I want to
> run all the unit tests of our project before checking-in"
> like XP mandates.
> Thus, your coworkers gain the ability to easily run the
> tests of the other
> workers.
>
> B-It helps automating the process, towards a true
> "continuous integration".
> Ant has already defined tasks for Junit.
>
> C-Some stuff often used when testing is in the junit
> framework. It saves you
> time to not have to write your own assert, etc..
>
> D-Extension packages : we are starting to see a lot of
> extensions to junit,
> integration with IDE, etc. These are nice to have and
> altought they
> certainly could be used without junit, it's even simpler with it.
>
> E-Gaining some experience with a tool that is more and
> more becoming the
> standard for writing unit test in java is a good
> opportunity. Your coworkers
> should at least try it.
>
> But why do YOU want them to use junit? What is your gain?
>
> If they already have a nice working setup, maybe there is
> not point in
> switching...
>
> mathieu
>
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: Jason Rogers
> To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
> Sent: Monday, June 11, 2001 8:58 AM
> Subject: RE: [junit] Why bother?
>
>
>
> > 2) My experience is that most people will write a main
> > that does NOT
> > automatically say, "yes, I passed all my tests". They
> > generally will print
> > out results, rather than asserting the truth. The
> > automatic behavior in
> > unit tests is key.
>
> To further David's point... my experience is that most
> main()'s test for
> best-case scenarios. They don't fully test the class.
>
> -Jason
